column7: Muamba de Galinha | A chicken stew flavored with palm oil and okra, sometimes containing palm nuts.
column8: Funje | A smooth, polenta-like side dish made from cassava flour.
column9: Kizaka | A type of leafy green, similar to spinach, often cooked in oil and garlic.

column7: Asado | A barbecue technique involving a range of meats, most notably beef, cooked on a grill called a 'parrilla' or an open fire.
column8: Empanadas | Crescent-shaped pastries filled with meats, cheese, or vegetables.
column9: Mate | A traditional caffeine-rich infused drink made from the leaves of the yerba mate plant.

column7: Vegemite | A thick, dark brown spread made from leftover brewers' yeast extract with various vegetable and spice additives.
column8: Lamingtons | Square-shaped sponge cake, coated in a layer of chocolate icing and desiccated coconut.
column9: Pavlova | A meringue-based dessert named after the Russian ballerina Anna Pavlova, with a crisp crust and soft, light inside, usually topped with fruit and whipped cream.

column7: Wiener Schnitzel | A breaded and fried veal cutlet that is a national dish.
column8: Sachertorte | A dense chocolate cake with a thin layer of apricot jam, traditionally served with whipped cream.
column9: Apfelstrudel | A strudel pastry jacket with an apple filling inside.

column7: Plov | A rice pilaf accompanied by various herbs and seasonings, sometimes with meats and dried fruits.
column8: Dolma | Grape leaves stuffed with minced meat and rice, often seasoned with mint and cinnamon.
column9: Baklava | Layers of filo pastry filled with nuts and sweetened with syrup or honey.

column7: Hilsa Fish Curry | A popular fish curry made with the national fish, hilsa, prepared with mustard seeds and spices.
column8: Pitha | A blanket term for cakes or dumplings made from rice flour or wheat flour, which can be sweet or savory.
column9: Falooda | A cold dessert with noodles, it includes ingredients such as rose syrup, vermicelli, and sweet basil seeds.

column7: Belgian Waffles | Often larger, lighter, and crispier, and have larger squares and deeper pockets than American waffles.
column8: Moules-frites | Mussels cooked or steamed with onions and celery served with fries.
column9: Belgian Chocolate | Renowned globally, often used in pralines, which are chocolate pieces filled with a soft fondant center.

column5: Bhutanese Ngultrum (BTN); Indian Rupee (INR) also accepted
column7: Ema Datshi | A spicy mix of chillies and the delicious local cheese known as datshi.
column8: Red Rice | A nutty-flavored rice that is the staple with most meals.
column9: Suja | Butter tea which includes tea leaves, yak butter, and salt.

column7: Feijoada | A hearty stew with black beans and a variety of pork and beef meats, which is traditionally served over rice with orange slices, collard greens, and farofa.
column8: Pão de Queijo | A popular snack and breakfast food, it's a small, baked, cheese-flavored roll.
column9: Caipirinha | The national cocktail, made with cachaça (sugarcane hard liquor), sugar, and lime.

column7: Ndolé | A stew consisting of stewed nuts, ndoleh (bitter leaves), and fish or beef.
column8: Fufu and Njama Njama | A dish consisting of pounded cassava (fufu) served with a sauce made from njama njama (huckleberry leaves) and palm oil.
column9: Kati Kati | Grilled chicken, seasoned and often enjoyed with a side of plantains or spicy sauce.

column7: Poutine | A dish consisting of fries topped with cheese curds and gravy.
column8: Butter Tarts | Small pastries filled with a butter, sugar, and egg filling.
column9: Caesar | A cocktail containing vodka, clamato juice, hot sauce, and Worcestershire sauce, typically served with ice in a large, celery salt-rimmed glass.

column5: Renminbi (RMB), commonly known as the Yuan (CNY)
column7: Peking Duck | A famous duck dish from Beijing that has been prepared since the imperial era, known for its thin, crispy skin.
column8: Dim Sum | Small bite-sized portions of food served in small steamer baskets or on small plates, usually for brunch.
column9: Baijiu | A clear, potent spirit made from grain, often consumed during festivities.

column5: Cambodian Riel (KHR); US Dollar (USD) widely accepted
column7: Amok | A creamy curry steamed in banana leaves, typically made with fish, coconut milk, and khmer spices.
column8: Lok lak | Stir-fried beef strips in a savory sauce, served with rice and sometimes with fried eggs on top.
column9: Nom Banh Chok | A Khmer noodle dish often eaten for breakfast, served with a fish-based green curry gravy.

column7: Bandeja Paisa | A platter that includes beans, rice, chicharrón, a fried egg, plantain, chorizo, arepa, and avocado.
column8: Arepa | A type of food made from ground maize dough or cooked flour prominent in the cuisine of Colombia and Venezuela.
column9: Aguapanela | A traditional and simple Colombian drink made from panela (unrefined whole cane sugar) dissolved in water.

column7: Ropa Vieja | Shredded beef stewed in tomato sauce, often served with black beans and rice.
column8: Moros y Cristianos | A mix of black beans and white rice, symbolizing the Moorish (black) and Christian (white) communities.
column9: Tostones | Twice-fried plantain slices, typically seasoned with salt and served as a snack or side dish.

column7: Svíčková | A dish typically consisting of marinated beef sirloin served with a creamy sauce and bread dumplings.
column8: Trdelník | A type of spit cake. It is made from rolled dough that is wrapped around a stick, then grilled and topped with sugar and walnut mix.
column9: Pilsner | A type of pale lager that takes its name from the city of Pilsen, where it was first produced in 1842.
